facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 116 of 1956 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 116 of 1956. Appeal from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and order dated December 22, 1955 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 714 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated December 22, 1955, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 714 of 1955, arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Calcutta High Court Criminal Revision No. 714 of 1955 arose out of judgment dated May 9, 1955 of Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore in Criminal Appeal No. 97 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: , arising out of the judgment and order dated May 9, 1955, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore in Criminal Appeal No. 97 of 1955. P. Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant's father Sailendra Sundar Mitra was tried and convicted by a Magistrate of the first class at Alipore.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants father, Sailendra Sundar Mitra, was tried and convicted by a Magistrate of the first class, at Alipore. The Appellate -Court has set out the case

facts.text: Charge against accused: on 2nd December 1946 at Garden Reach, accused as Establishment Clerk of B.C. II Section in Traffic Accounts Office of B.N. Railway cheated by false representation in pay bill for November 1946 delivering Rs. 205-13-0 excess to himself and Rs. 33-4-0 to Satish Chandra Das Gupta under section 420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the accused was that on the 2nd December, 1946, at Garden Reach, the accused, being an employee as Establishment Clerk of B. C. II Section in the Traffic Accounts Office of B. N. Railway  cheated the said B. N. Railway Administration by dishonestly inducing it by means of false representation in the pay bill of the  number-gazetted staff for November, 1946, to deliver to him Rs. 205-13-0 and to one Satish Chandra Das Gupta, a clerk in the said B. C. 11 Section, Rs. 33-4-0 in excess of legitimate dues, and thereby companymitted an offence punishable under section 420, P.C.

facts.text: Trial Magistrate convicted accused for cheating in respect of Rs. 205-13-0 but gave benefit of doubt for Rs. 33-4-0.

anchor.surface_text: The learned trial Magistrate convicted the accused person for cheating in respect of Rs. 205-13-0, but gave him the benefit of the doubt in respect of the sum of Rs. 33-4-0 claimed on behalf of another person, named Satish Chandra Das Gupta.

facts.text: Magistrate sentenced accused to one day's imprisonment (detention till rising of court), fine of Rs. 500, in default rigorous imprisonment for six months.

anchor.surface_text: He sentenced the accused to suffer one days imprisonment  really, detention till the rising of the companyrt, on the day the order was pronounced , and to pay a fine of Rs. 500/-, and in default, to rigorous imprisonment for six months, more.

facts.text: Magistrate directed Rs. 333 out of fine to B.N. Railway as compensation by order dated February 11, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: He also directed that out of the fine, if realised, Rs. 333/- shall be paid to the B.N. Railway Administration  number, the South Eastern Railway  as companypensation, by his order dated February 11, 1955.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore dismissed the appeal and confirmed conviction and sentence on May 9, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the learned Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore  24, Parganas , after hearing the parties, dismissed the appeal, and confirmed the orders of companyviction and sentence passed by the learned trial Magistrate, by his judgment dated May 9, 1955.

facts.text: Accused filed revision in Calcutta High Court under s.439 CrPC, registered as Criminal Revision Case No. 714 of 1955, rule issued, stayed realization of fine.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the judgment and orders of the companyrts below, the accused aforesaid moved the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction, under s. 439 of the Code. The High Court issued a Rule which was registered as Criminal Revision Case No. 714 of 1955, and stayed the realization of the fine pending the hearing of the Rule.

facts.text: Accused died on July 8, 1955, leaving widow and five children all minors except the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the case in the High Court, the accused person died on July 8, 1955, leaving him surviving his widow and five children, all of whom were minors except the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant applied on December 6, 1955 to be added as heir and party to continue the revision challenging conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application on December 6, 1955, stating that he was one of the heirs of the deceased accused  petitioner in the High Court , and that he was interested in proceeding with the criminal revision case, and challenging the order of companyviction and sentence, passed against his deceased father.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court on December 22, 1955 allowed substitution for sentence of fine, held conviction not challengeable, reduced fine to Rs. 205-13-0 payable to B.N. Railway.

anchor.surface_text: the Bench passed its order on the application on December 22, 1955, holding that the principle of s. 431 of the Code, applied to a criminal revisional application even when there was a companyposite sentence but only in so far as the sentence of fine was companycerned. The application for substitution , as the Division Bench of the High Court has characterized it, was heard, and. ... In view of the fact that the defence of the accused person was that he had over-charged on account of a mistake, and that he was prepared to refund the excess amount, the High Court directed that the sentence of fine be reduced to the sum charged in excess, namely, Rs. 205/13/-. It also directed that the whole of the amount of fine, if realized, shall be paid to the B.N. Railway Administration  number South Eastern Railway .

facts.text: Appellant obtained certificate of fitness from High Court under Article 134(1)(c) Constitution for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Being dissatisfied with the aforesaid order of the High Court, the appellant moved the High Court and obtained the necessary certificate of fitness from the High Court. Hence, this appeal on a certificate under art. 134  1   c  of the Constitution, granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Defence of accused was over-charging due to mistake and prepared to refund excess.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the fact that the defence of the accused person was that he had over-charged on account of a mistake, and that he was prepared to refund the excess amount,

facts.text: Section 431 CrPC provides appeals under certain sections abate on death of accused, others except from fine abate on death of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberrelevant provision in the Code, except s. 431 which is the last section in Chapter XXXI of the Code, dealing with appeals, and is in these terms- Every appeal under section 411A, subsection  2 , or section 417 shall finally abate on the death of the accused, and every other appeal under this Chapter  except an appeal from a sentence of fine  shall finally abate on the death of the appellant.

facts.text: Accused had served out his nominal sentence of imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: the companyvicted person had served out his numberinal sentence of imprisonment  assuming that it was a legal sentence of imprisonment ,

facts.text: In re Nabishab case: two convicted of breach of trust, sentenced 1 year RI and Rs1000 fine, one died during appeal, surviving appeal allowed, relative applied in revision for dead, held abated under s431.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Criminal Procedure Code of 1882  Act 10 of 1882 , for the first time, introduced s. That section came up for companysideration before a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court in its criminal revisional jurisdiction in the case of In re Nabishab  1 . Shortly stated, the facts in that case were that two persons had been companyvicted of criminal breach of trust, and each one was sentenced to one years rigorous. imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000. Both the companyvicted persons appealed to the High Court. One of them died during the pendency of the appeal.

facts.text: Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji: accused sentenced 4 years RI and Rs1000 fine for forgery, died in jail during appeal without bail.

anchor.surface_text: Such a situation arose in the case of Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji  1 . In that case, the accused person was sentenced, on a charge of forgery, to four years rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1,000 by the Court of Session. During the pendency of the appeal in the High Court, the appellant, who had number been released on bail, died in jail.

facts.text: Appellant P. Lal argued for appellant, J. Umrigar and R. H. Dhebar for respondents.

anchor.surface_text: P. Lal, for the appellant. J. Umrigar and R. H. Dhebar, for the respondents. 1958. October 3.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SINHA J. on October 3, 1958.

issues.text: whether a pending application in revision made under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure finally abates on the death of the petitioner in the High Court, and if so, to what extent.

anchor.surface_text: is whether a pending application in revision made under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be referred to hereinafter as the Code , finally abates on the death of the petitioner in the High Court, and if so, to what extent.

issues.text: whether the High Court was right in limiting its power of revision to the question of fine only - whether it was proper or unduly severe - without going into the merits of the order of conviction.
whether an appeal would abate if it is from a conviction and sentence not only of fine but also of imprisonment though it may be till the rising of the court.

anchor.surface_text: we need not go into the question whether an appeal would abate if it is from a conviction and sentence not only of fine but also of imprisonment though it may be till the rising of the court.

arguments.claim: Heir of the deceased accused can be added as a party to continue the criminal revision case and challenge the order of conviction and sentence passed against the deceased father.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant made an application on December 6, 1955, stating that he was one of the heirs of the deceased accused  petitioner in the High Court , and that he was interested in proceeding with the criminal revision case, and challenging the order of conviction and sentence, passed against his deceased father.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court holds that revisions do not abate on death and High Court has discretion to allow substitution and examine conviction.

arguments.claim: The principle of s.431 CrPC applies to a criminal revisional application even with a composite sentence, but only insofar as the sentence of fine is concerned.

anchor.surface_text: holding that the principle of s. 431 of the Code, applied to a criminal revisional application even when there was a composite sentence but only in so far as the sentence of fine was concerned.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e, to be determined on first principles. It appears that the Criminal Procedure Code of 1882  Act 10 of 1882 , for the first time, introduced s. That

arguments.court_reasoning: s.431 in terms applies only to appeals under Chapter XXXI, not to revisions; revisions governed by first principles and discretionary powers under s.439.

arguments.claim: The conviction cannot be challenged in revision after the death of the petitioner because the sentence was composite (imprisonment and fine), so revisional application survives only to examine if fine was proper or unduly severe.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also ruled that the conviction could not be challenged inasmuch as the sentence was a composite one of imprisonment as also fine, and that, therefore, the revisional application would survive only to the limited extent whether the sentence of fine was proper or unduly severe.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court has full revisional powers under s.439 to examine correctness, legality, propriety of conviction and sentence; limiting to fine only is improper as conviction must be examined to assess fine.

arguments.claim: Section 431 CrPC applies only to appeals and lays down abatement rules specifically for appeals against acquittal and other appeals except from fine.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the section, in terms, applies only to appeals, and lays down that an appeal against an order of acquittal passed by the High Court in exercise of its original criminal jurisdiction  s. 411-A  2  , or an appeal to the High Court from an order of acquittal passed by any court other than the High Court, shall finally abate upon the death of the accused, and all appeals under Chapter XXXI, except an appeal from a sentence of fine, shall finally abate on the death of the appellant.

arguments.claim: s.431 does not apply to applications in revision; such cases must be determined on first principles.

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, s. 431, in terms, does not apply to such a case. The case has, therefore, to be determined on first principles.

arguments.claim: Revisional powers under s.439 CrPC do not create any right in the litigant but conserve the High Court's power to ensure justice, prevent excess/abuse by subordinate courts; unlike statutory right of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional powers of the High Court vested in it by s. 439 of the Code, read with s. 435, do not create any right in the litigant, but only conserve the power of the High Court to see that justice is done in accordance with the recognized rules of Criminal Jurisprudence, and that subordinate criminal courts do not exceed their jurisdiction, or abuse their powers vested in them by the Code. On the other hand, as already indicated, a right of appeal is a statutory right which has got to be recognized by the courts

arguments.claim: Legislature did not extend s.431 abatement to revisions despite awareness of decisions; revisions left to High Court's discretion per exigencies.

anchor.surface_text: We may assume that the Legislature was aware of the decision of the Bombay High Court, referred to above, when it enacted s. 431 for the first time in the Code of 1882. If the Legislature intended that all application in revision pending in a High Court, should be dealt with on the same footing as a pending appeal, it would have enacted accordingly. But in the absence of any such enactment, we may infer that the power of revision vested in the High Court under Chapter XXXII of the Code, was left untouched-to be exercised according to the exigencies of each case.

arguments.qualifiers: we may assume, we may infer

arguments.claim: High Court has complete discretion on death of petitioner in revision: not bound to abate or substitute; to deal per requirements of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is not bound to entertain an application in revision, or having entertained one, to order substitution in every case. It is not bound the other way, namely, to treat a pending application in revision as having abated by reason of the fact that there was a composite sentence of imprisonment and fine, as some of the single Judge decisions placed before us, would seem to indicate. The High Court has been left complete discretion to deal with a pending matter on the death of the petitioner in accordance with the requirements of justice.

arguments.claim: High Court must hear and determine issued rule under s.439 regardless of whether petitioner alive or dead.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it was an accused person or it was a complainant who has moved the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction, if the High Court has issued a Rule, that Rule has to be heard and determined in accordance with law, whether or not the petitioner in the High Court is alive or dead, or whether he is represented in court by a legal practitioner.

arguments.claim: Considerations of abatement in appeals do not apply to revisional applications as High Court supervises administration of justice.
Bombay High Court majority decision in Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji lays down the correct approach for revisions post-death.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the absence of statutory provisions, in terms applying to an application in revision, as there are those in s. 431 in respect of criminal appeals, the High Court has the power to pass such orders as to it may seem fit and proper, in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction vested in it by s. 439 of the Code. ... the Bombay majority decision  1 , in the absence of any statutory provisions in respect of criminal revisional cases, lays down the correct approach.

arguments.claim: Single Judge decisions applying s.431 principle by analogy to revisions are incorrect.
High Court cannot limit revisional power to fine only without examining merits of conviction; must examine conviction to determine propriety of fine.
In Nabishab case, revision by relative after appeal abatement was refused as it depended on evidence appreciation and involved substantive imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by the High Court, without discussing the terms of the section and without giving any reasons for that conclusion, that the appeal in respect of the dead man had abated under s. 431 of the Code. The High Court refused to deal with the case in its revisional jurisdiction on the ground that the case depended upon appreciation of evidence.

arguments.court_reasoning: Noted but not relied upon as lacking reasons.

arguments.claim: In Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji, appeal abates on death; legal representative cannot continue appeal; High Court can exercise revision suo motu but not bound.

anchor.surface_text: He also held that though the appeal had abated, the High Court had the power to call for the record and exercise its revisional jurisdiction suo motu, but he did not express any opinion whether in the case before the Court, such a power could be exercised.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees that in absence of statute, High Court has revisional power post-death.

holdings.text: Section 431 CrPC applies only to appeals under Chapter XXXI and does not apply to criminal revisions under s.439.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the section, in terms, applies only to appeals, and lays down that an appeal against an order of acquittal passed by the High Court in exercise of its original criminal jurisdiction  s. 411-A  2  , or an appeal to the High Court from an order of acquittal passed by any companyrt other than the High Court, shall finally abate upon the death of the accused, and all appeals under Chapter XXXI, except an appeal from a sentence of fine, shall finally abate on the death of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.431 limiting it expressly to appeals; revisions governed separately under Chapter XXXII.

holdings.text: A pending criminal revision under s.439 CrPC does not abate on the death of the petitioner and is to be determined on first principles.

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, s. 431, in terms, does number apply to such a case. The case has, therefore, to be determined on first principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of statutory abatement provision for revisions requires application of first principles distinguishing from appeals.

holdings.text: High Court has power and complete discretion under s.439 to pass fit orders in revision even after death of petitioner, including substitution of heirs.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the absence of statutory provisions, in terms applying to an application in revision, as there are those in s. 431 in respect of criminal appeals, the High Court has the power to pass such orders as to it may seem fit and proper, in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction vested in it by s. 439 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supervisory revisional jurisdiction discretionary, not creating litigant right; legislature left untouched despite awareness of appeals abatement.

holdings.text: Revisional powers under s.439 do not create any right in the litigant but conserve High Court's supervisory power to ensure justice.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional powers of the High Court vested in it by s. 439 of the Code, read with s. 435, do number create any right in the litigant, but only companyserve the power of the High Court to see that justice is done in accordance with the recognized rules of Criminal Jurisprudence, and that subordinate criminal companyrts do number exceed their jurisdiction, or abuse their powers vested in them by the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrast with statutory appeal right; revision for justice supervision, not personal right subject to abatement.

holdings.text: High Court must hear and determine a rule issued under s.439 regardless of whether petitioner is alive or dead.

anchor.surface_text: Whether it was an accused person or it was a companyplainant who has moved the High Court in its revisional jurisdiction, if the High Court has issued a Rule, that Rule has to be beard and determined in accordance with law, whether or number the petitioner in the High Court is alive or dead, or whether he is represented in companyrt by a legal practitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Once rule issued, High Court duty to determine for administration of justice.

holdings.text: Bombay High Court majority decision in Imperatrix v. Dongaji Andaji lays down the correct approach for revisions on death of petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the Bombay majority decision  1 , in the absence of any statutory provisions in respect of criminal revisional cases, lays down the companyrect approach.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsement of precedent allowing revisional disposal post-death absent statute.

holdings.text: Single Judge decisions applying s.431 principle by analogy to revisions are incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: There are a number of decisions in the books, mostly of Judges sitting singly, that though s. 431, in terms, does number apply to revisional applications, the principle of that section applied to such cases. It is number necessary to refer to those cases specifically.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No basis for analogy where statute silent; first principles govern.

holdings.text: High Court was not right in limiting revisional power to sentence of fine only without examining merits of conviction.

anchor.surface_text: it number remains to companysider whether the High Court war, right in limiting its power of revision to the question of fine only- whether it was proper or excessive-without going into the merits of the order of companyviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full s.439 powers include examining conviction merits to assess fine propriety, especially when fine from estate.

holdings.text: High Court has power under s.439 to examine correctness, legality, propriety of conviction and sentence of fine in revision post-death.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Propriety of fine requires conviction scrutiny; heir interest in estate justifies full examination.

anchor.surface_text: It is manifest that the section, in terms, applies only to appeals, and lays down that an appeal against an order of acquittal passed by the High Court in exercise of its original criminal jurisdiction  s. 411-A  2  , or an appeal to the High Court from an order of acquittal passed by any companyrt other than the High Court, shall finally abate upon the death of the accused, and all appeals under Chapter XXXI, except an appeal from a sentence of fine, shall finally abate on the death of the appellant.

In our opinion, therefore, where the High Court thinks it fit and proper to entertain an application in revision or calls for the record suo motu, it has the power to examine the whole question of the correctness, propriety or legality of the sentence of fine, which necessarily involves examining the order of conviction itself from that point of view.

anchor.surface_text: As already indicated, s. 431, in terms, does number apply to such a case. The case has, therefore, to be determined on first principles.

In our opinion, therefore, where the High Court thinks it fit and proper to entertain an application in revision or calls for the record suo motu, it has the power to examine the whole question of the correctness, propriety or legality of the sentence of fine, which necessarily involves examining the order of conviction itself from that point of view.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the absence of statutory provisions, in terms applying to an application in revision, as there are those in s. 431 in respect of criminal appeals, the High Court has the power to pass such orders as to it may seem fit and proper, in exercise of its revisional jurisdiction vested in it by s. 439 of the Code.

In our opinion, therefore, where the High Court thinks it fit and proper to entertain an application in revision or calls for the record suo motu, it has the power to examine the whole question of the correctness, propriety or legality of the sentence of fine, which necessarily involves examining the order of conviction itself from that point of view.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional powers of the High Court vested in it by s. 439 of the Code, read with s. 435, do number create any right in the litigant, but only companyserve the power of the High Court to see that justice is done in accordance with the recognized rules of Criminal Jurisprudence, and that subordinate criminal companyrts do number exceed their jurisdiction, or abuse their powers vested in them by the Code.

In our opinion, therefore, where the High Court thinks it fit and proper to entertain an application in revision or calls for the record suo motu, it has the power to examine the whole question of the correctness, propriety or legality of the sentence of fine, which necessarily involves examining the order of conviction itself from that point of view.
